timeline.body: Is there a specific reason we do windowing only for iterable case?
timeline.bodyText: Is there a specific reason we do windowing only for iterable case?
timeline.bodyHTML: Is there a specific reason we do windowing only for iterable case?
timeline.author: Ardagan

replies.bodyText: As I understand it, all SideInput types except for Iterable are cached, so windowing shouldn't change much in other scenarios. I can add it to other cases anyway
replies.author: mwalenia

timeline.body:
What are the metrics? Should they be described in the Javadoc? I read the superclass and did not see much explanation there either.

The code here makes OK sense but is not enough information to use it. So I am just wondering what the experience is for someone who wants to use the class to build a new load test.

replies.bodyText: The metrics are runtime and dataset size. I can document the LoadTest class a bit better in another PR if you think current state is not helpful enough
replies.author: mwalenia

timeline.body:
I just noticed `runtimeMonitor` is a `protected` field. It seems there are actually a few, and you have built enough on top that it may be getting hard to change. But even though I am late, I offer a suggestion for refactor: make `LoadTest` parameterized instead of a base class.

Each subclass of `LoadTest` is really just the main `loadTest` function and really that function is about the same as writing a `PTransform`. If you eliminate subclassing you can have `LoadTest` own the pipeline setup with so it will never be possible to forget or mess up `readSourceFromOptions` and `ParDo.of(runtimeMonitor)`. It will be less repeat boilerplate. Also you won't have to reference variables defined in another file as protected fields.

If you eliminate subclassing you can have LoadTest own the pipeline setup with so it will never be possible to forget or mess up readSourceFromOptions and ParDo.of(runtimeMonitor). It will be less repeat boilerplate. Also you won't have to reference variables defined in another file as protected fields.

replies.bodyText: I think we can talk about refactoring of the load tests in another context, let's keep this PR focused on the load test. WDYT?
replies.author: mwalenia

replies.bodyText: I see that one option is to create Jira with list of improvements and work on it in next PR. This will make it easier to review both cases.
replies.author: Ardagan

replies.bodyText:
@kennknowles how do you envision this refactor? I don't see how we can parametrize the LoadTest further (it's already parametrized with options class). What we can do is move some of the boilerplate up to the LoadTest class, so that some of source reading is done automatically.
I will be grateful for your input in this matter.
replies.author: mwalenia

timeline.body: This tests `Map`, not `HashMap`. The runner (or SDK harness in portability) can choose whatever kind of `Map` it wants.
timeline.bodyText: This tests Map, not HashMap. The runner (or SDK harness in portability) can choose whatever kind of Map it wants.
timeline.bodyHTML: This tests Map, not HashMap. The runner (or SDK harness in portability) can choose whatever kind of Map it wants.
timeline.author: kennknowles

timeline.body: It is worth documenting that the whole point of `View.asList` is to force it all to be read into memory so it is fast to iterate multiple times or access a given index. You could test these, too. If you don't need either of those, then `View.asIterable` will access lazily so it will often perform better and scale larger.

timeline.body: For `View.asIterable` it makes the most sense to scan a random distance into the iterable. The most important use case is when you cannot read it all into a list, I think. Both cases are interesting: reading the whole iterable and reading just a prefix.

timeline.body: This part doesn't work well at high scale for some map implementations. An important use case is accessing just some keys and not others. A runner/SDK may have a separate place where they write the keySet so that you can make this call efficiently. But they may not. We don't want to make this test so sensitive to that (you could separate test efficiency of keySet). Can you calculate random keys in advance based on `sourceOptions`?

replies.bodyText: I don't know if it's possible - I'll look into it
replies.author: mwalenia

replies.bodyText: I think calculating the keys beforehand would add a huge code overhead to the tests. I'm also still unsure how would I go about that. If you really think it would be worth it - can you give me some pointers regarding the approach to this issue?
replies.author: mwalenia
